questions.question: What is Matter?
possibleAnswers: Anything that has mass and volume
questions.correctAnswer: Anything that has mass and volume

questions.question: Which of these branches of Chemistry deals with carbon-based compounds?
What is the difference between pure research and applied research?
possibleAnswers: Pure research is done to discover new elements, while applied research is done to synthesize new compounds
Pure research is done for the sake of knowledge, while applied research is done to solve a specific problem
Pure research involves only qualitative observations, while applied research uses a lot of quantitative observations
questions.correctAnswer: Pure research is done for the sake of knowledge, while applied research is done to solve a specific problem

questions.question: Why is it necessary to have controlling variables?
possibleAnswers: To ensure that effects on the dependent variable are caused exclusively by the independent variable
To ensure that the experiment can be replicated
To ensure the safety of those performing the lab
questions.correctAnswer: To ensure that effects on the dependent variable are caused exclusively by the independent variable

questions.question: How is mass different from weight?
possibleAnswers: Mass is the amount of matter in an object, while weight is the effect of gravity on an object
Mass is the effect of gravity on an object, while weight is the amount of matter in an object
questions.correctAnswer: Mass is the amount of matter in an object, while weight is the effect of gravity on an object

questions.question: What safety tool should you use when working with chemicals that give off harmful fumes?
What safety device should be worn at all times while working in the lab?
What should you do if a fire drill occurs during a lab
possibleAnswers: turn off gas valves, electrical equipment, etc

questions.question: What could happen if hot glassware is submerged in cold water?
Why is tying up loose hair necessary?
possibleAnswers: loose hair could catch on fire
loose hair could get caught on laboratory equipment

questions.question: Which subatomic particle is not found in the nucleus?
Which subatomic particle has no charge?
Why do different isotopes of the same element have different atomic masses?
possibleAnswers: Because they have different amounts of electrons
Because they have different amounts of neutrons
Because they have different amounts of protons
questions.correctAnswer: Because they have different amounts of neutrons

questions.question: How many neutrons does Potassium-41 have?
Do different isotopes of the same element react differently? Why?
possibleAnswers: Yes, because the reactivity of elements depends on the element's neutrons
No, because the reactivity of elements depends on the element's electrons
No, because the reactivity of elements depends on the element's protons
questions.correctAnswer: No, because the reactivity of elements depends on the element's electrons

questions.question: Is an electron a wave or a particle?
Which electron configuration principle states that a maximum of two electrons may occupy an orbital?
What is the electron configuration of Silicon?
What is the electron configuration of Lithium?
Why is it impossible to observe the exact position of an electron?
possibleAnswers: Because the act of observing the position changes the position
questions.correctAnswer: Because the act of observing the position changes the position

questions.question: Halogens are located in what group?
What is the name for the ability of an electron to attract electrons
As you move across a period from left to right, the atomic radii of the elements tends to
As you move down a group from top to bottom, the electronegativity of elements tends to
Why does the atomic radii decrease as you move across a period from left to right?
possibleAnswers: The extra protons create extra force that pulls electrons closer to the nucleus
The atomic radii does not decrease
Elements on the right side of the periodic table have less electrons
questions.correctAnswer: The extra protons create extra force that pulls electrons closer to the nucleus

questions.question: What is the name for an atom that has lost or gained electrons?
What is a cation?
possibleAnswers: an atom that has lost or gained two electrons

questions.question: Name the following compound: Na₂S
Name the following compound: NiBr₂
Why do ionic compounds have high melting and boiling points
possibleAnswers: Because their crystal lattice structure requires a lot of energy to break
Ionic compounds do not have high melting and boiling points
questions.correctAnswer: Because their crystal lattice structure requires a lot of energy to break

questions.question: What is the name for a bond where electrons are shared?
What two types of covalent bonds must be be present in a multiple covalent bond
Name the following molecule: H₂CO₃
What is the formula of Phosphorus Triflouride?
Why are double bonds stronger than single bonds
possibleAnswers: There are more shared electron pairs

questions.question: Which of the following suffixes is used with Ionic Compounds?
How many molecules of Chlorine are there in Carbon Tetrachloride?
What is the name of the following molecule: BCl₃
What is the chemical formula of Ammonium Iodide?
What determines whether the state of matter for an Ionic Compound is Aqueous or Solid?
possibleAnswers: If the element/compound is near the top of the activity series, it is Aqueous

questions.question: Which type of chemical reaction has one compound as a reactant and multiple products?
For which type of reaction must you consult the activity series to see if it would occur?
Which of the following is the correctly balanced form of Ca + H²O → Ca(OH)² + H²?
Identify the substance being oxidized in the following equation: CH₄ + 2O² → CO² + 2H²O
What is the defining characteristic of a redox reaction?
possibleAnswers: The product side of the equation has less oxygen molecules than the reactants side of the equation

questions.question: Which of these is Avogadro's Number?
One mole of a gas at STP is equal to how many liters?
What is the mass of 1.107 ✕ 10²⁴ molecules of Gold?
What is the molar mass of Potassium Oxide?
Why are moles used in Chemistry?
possibleAnswers: They provide an easier way than to represent the amount of a substance than to deal with the number of molecules
To make it easier to calculate the total charge of an ion
To determine the state of matter of an element(If the moles of an element exceeds its molar mass, the element is Aqueous)
questions.correctAnswer: They provide an easier way than to represent the amount of a substance than to deal with the number of molecules

questions.question: What is a limiting Reagent?
possibleAnswers: The reactant that is depleted first and causes the reaction to stop
A type of catalyst added to make a chemical reaction stop after a certain amount of the reactants have been used up
A chemical that prevents a reaction from occurring
questions.correctAnswer: The reactant that is depleted first and causes the reaction to stop

questions.question: In order to have correct mole ratios, what has to be done to a chemical equation?
possibleAnswers: The molar mass of each product and reactant has to be calculated
states of matter have to be added

questions.question: What is the mole ratio of Rubidium Nitrate to Oxygen in RbNO₃ → RbNO₂ + O₂?
How many grams of Silver Phosphate are produced if 3.20 moles of Silver Nitrate react with 2.70 moles of Potassium Phosphate?
Which of these is NOT a valid reason for why 100% yield is impossible?
possibleAnswers: Some of the reactant is used in an unwanted, competing reaction
Some of the reactant or product evaporates

questions.question: What is the term for when a solid turns straight into a gas?
Is burning a piece of paper a physical of chemical change?
The process of separating a mixture based based on the substances' varying boiling points is called:
What is the difference between a heterogeneous mixture and a homogeneous mixture?
possibleAnswers: A heterogeneous mixture has an uneven distribution of its substances, while a homogeneous mixture has an even distribution
A homogeneous mixture has an uneven distribution of its substances, while a heterogeneous mixture has an even distribution
The terms can be used interchangeably
questions.correctAnswer: A heterogeneous mixture has an uneven distribution of its substances, while a homogeneous mixture has an even distribution

questions.question: How does Chromatography work?
possibleAnswers: The mixture is dissolved in either a liouid or gas, and then it moves across a fixed substrate. Some substances move faster than others, so the mixture is separated.
The mixture is boiled. Since each substance has a different boiling point, the substance is separated
questions.correctAnswer: The mixture is dissolved in either a liouid or gas, and then it moves across a fixed substrate. Some substances move faster than others, so the mixture is separated.

questions.question: What is a solvent?
possibleAnswers: A substance that another substance is dissolved in
A mixture that contains a liquid, and another substance dissolved in that liquid
questions.correctAnswer: The substance that another substance is dissolved in

questions.question: What is a solute?
possibleAnswers: A substance that another substance is dissolved in
A mixture that contains a liquid, and another substance dissolved in that liquid

questions.question: What is the molarity of 35.00 grams of NaCl dissolved in 10 liters of water?
1 liter of a 0.05 M Lithium Chloride Solution is diluted by adding 1 liter of solvent. What is the new molarity of the solution?
Why do some substances dissolve in water?
possibleAnswers: Most dissolved particles are polar, and their polarity keeps them from getting to close or too far from other particles. This keeps them suspended in water
They are pulled apart by the water molecules
They have a lower density than water, so they can't settle at the bottom
questions.correctAnswer: They are pulled apart by the water molecules

questions.question: Which gas law relates Temperature and Volume?
What must be kept constant in order for Boyle's Law to work?
A gas at a constant temperature has a pressure of 1 atm and a volume of 3 liters. If the pressure is decreased to 0.25 atm, what is the new volume?
A gas has a pressure of 5 atm, a volume of 10 liters, and a temperature of 100 K. If the pressure is increased to 6 atm and the temperature decreased to 50 K, what is the new volume?
Why is the Ideal Gas Law not entirely accurate?
possibleAnswers: It assumes that gas particles have no mass
It assumes that gas particles have no volume
questions.correctAnswer: It assumes that gas particles have no volume
